captions.text:
You set out to just put
out something definitive

about litter boxes and sort
of Litter Box Etiquette 101.

And it's just like the
Alice in Wonderland

rabbit hole just like
filled with poop instead,

because you're just
constantly digging and digging
and digging.
There's more stuff.
There's more stuff.
OK.

Well, we're going to continue,
because there is never
a last word on litter boxes.
Let's catify the world.
Come on.

So the last time we were
talking about really Litter Box

101, things you may not
have known about the way

your cat sees their territory
vis-a-vis their litter boxes

and what you can do to help
secure their territory,

make it more appropriate for
them to use a litter box,

and at the end of the
day make you happy.

Let's have some general
rules on board here.

Number one, that old
adage is actually right.

If you have two cats, you want
two boxes, plus one, three
boxes.
Three cats, four boxes.
One cat, two boxes.

That makes sure that the
cats can territorially

identify the entire home,
so put those boxes out.
That leads me to the next thing.
Put them out.

I don't want to see
you saying to me,

I have three litter boxes,
Jackson, just like you said.

And all three of
those boxes are side

by side in a corner
in the garage.

You have to put
them in places that

are-- don't kill me--
socially important places.

How many people have said
this, cats want privacy?
Hmm.

So you're saying
that your cat wants

to go into a cabinet that's
disguised as a litter box.
That's ridiculous.

If your cat had it
her way, she would

be outside pooping and
peeing in a bush right

outside your door to
mark that territory.
She doesn't need privacy.
You do.

You don't want to be taking
a look at your cat pee
and pooping around the house.

And what happens then, you'll
put them in the mud room.

You'll put them behind
the washing machine.

You'll put them under
the car in the garage.

You'll put them where you
don't have to look at them.

And folks, I am telling you,
if you want to solve litter box

problems in your home,
make the opposite choice

that your aesthetic it
is telling you to make.

If cat is insecure and marking
certain areas because they

don't feel secure about that
area, putting a litter box

there is really important,
because at the very least

you can praise them for
doing something right,

as opposed to damning them
for doing something wrong.

And the next thing is, I put
a little box in the dining

room or the living
room or my bedroom,
just like you asked me to do.
I resent the hell out of it.
But I did it.
What's the next thing you do?

You plug in air fresheners
around the thing.

You deodorize the hell
out of that litter box.
That drives cats away.

So no plug-in deodorizers,
no sprinkle-on deodorizers.

I don't really believe
in scented litter at all.

If you consistently scoop your
cat's stuff out of the litter

box, you're not going to have
to worry about that smell.

Now I want to bring
up one more thing

about preventing
litter box problems.
Catification is a big thing.
What is catification?

We've talked about
this one before.

It is environmental
enrichment for cats,

but also environmental
enrichment

that doesn't preclude
your aesthetic sense.

Yes, you can have things
that work for your cats
and work for you the same time.

So let's take for
instance, the litter box
that everybody seems to have.

It's a litter box where
you've got a big hood on it.

And then what you do is you
take the opening to the hood

and you face it to the wall,
because for some reason

humans do not like
looking at litter.

Wherever they go in, they got
to know they can get out again.

There has got to
be an escape route.

So if they are in that litter
box with that hole facing

the wall and another
cat or a dog or a child

comes up behind
them, they're surely

not going to go
back to a box where
they get ambushed and cornered.

So when you're looking
at litter boxes

and how you place
them around the house,

you've got to make sure
your cats have exit routes
everywhere.

A lot of cats have almost a
post-traumatic stress reaction

to the litter box
where either they

were ambushed by another cat or
it used to hurt to pee there.

And what you're
going to need to do

is start collecting litter
boxes that look and feel

and nothing like the
litter box that you've

been using, just because we
can build a new association.

Does that mean get
rid of the old one?
No.
It means add another one.

If you have a big,
square, deep box,

you go for something very
shallow, something round,

a different type of
litter altogether.

And you put it
around the house, let

them choose where I want to go,
what kind of litter I prefer,
what's the depth I like.

And then you can slowly start
replacing the boxes that

were offensive to your
cat to begin with.

There's so much
more to talk about.
But here's the exciting part.

I don't think there's any way
we can encapsulate this all

and me just talking to
a camera and talking
to you through my camera.

I think it's time to
bring you into it.

So the next time we
have a Google Hangout,

which is coming up
really soon, we're

going to take the questions
that most are asking.

And I know I'm
missing something.

And you're going to fill
me in on what I'm missing.

So down in the
comments section below,

start writing your
questions for me.
I want them to be in general.

I don't want to hear, I
have cat who dot, dot, dot,

because the question is
going to be this long.

And I've got to tell you,
folks, it's not going to read.

I want to have questions
that everybody can relate to.

And I will try to
answer them all.

And then, if you actually
watch the description below,

it'll give you
instructions on how

to get involved with the
Hangout, how you and me can go

a little mano a mano live
in front of everybody

through the magic of
Google and hanging out.

You can find me on Twitter
and Facebook and YouTube.
Obviously, you found me there.
My website, jacksongalaxy.com.

You can find me just about
in any of the social media

nooks and crannies and find out
when that Hangout is happening,

and also when we've got
new "My Cat From Hell,"

which, by the way,
August 23rd, new episodes

of "My Cat From
Hell," season five.

Until the next
time we talk, just

keep your head in the litter
box and keep your hands out
of the litter box.
Think inside the box.
Think outside the box.
Just get more boxes.
How about that?
All light.
All love.
All mojo to you.
I'll talk to you soon.
Love you.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: You’re Setting Up Your Litter Box All Wrong!

comments.text:
my boy uses his box. but hes pooping in my bath tub. the litter box is 
right next to the tub.He use to poop in the tray, but i don't know if its 
him viewing the tub as another litter tray? or if he just wants a seperate 
place to poop? i can clean poop out daily but doesn't seem to matter. I 
don't necessarily care, as its easy enough to clean, but isn't a great 
habit to let him continue doing. Advice?﻿
comments.author: ray lloyd

comments.text:
Oh and no matter how many cats, 1 litter box was fine as long as it 
maintained a fairly clean status﻿
comments.author: Julie House

comments.text:
I only watched the 1/2 this video, and I can tell you this is good to know 
if you have incredibly stupid cats. I have lived in many different types 
and sizes of homes 2 story mobile apartment it does not matter. Every cat 
or kitten I've ever had, failed to use the litter box 1 time. When I 1st 
brought them home. I grabbed the kitty, brought it to and made sure it 
could see and smell the accident and put them in the litter box. That's it. 
I even brought home a kitten that could not be more than 4 weeks old, that 
I found on a hwy. And this method worked﻿
comments.author: Julie House

comments.text:
We never had problems. We always had two cats and one litter box in the 
hallway and it was covered and all was well﻿
comments.author: fhhh

comments.text:
I dunno my cat does like people watching him going to the bathroom he 
actually stops going to the bathroom when you look at him going. So I think 
it depends on the cat﻿
comments.author: steven cutcher

comments.text:
I use to have a cat that would pee in my room but poop in the littler box. 
We had his liter box in something that covered him up because we thought he 
wanted privacy. What we did was just got him a box where he could get out 
of that wasn't covered up and I started to increase the depth of the 
litter. Sure enough he stopped peeing in my room and started doing 
everything in his littler box. That cat was very picky about things but he 
was an awesome cat. When my step mom moved out she took him with her to a 
different state, I really miss him. :(﻿
comments.author: GordanFreeman23

comments.text:
Hey Jackson my cat poops n pees in the litter box but every so often starts 
in there but then comes out with poop on his but and does the scoot across 
my carpet. WHY? ﻿
comments.author: alicia falotico

comments.text:
what do you suggest for people who have large but not fat domestic cats who 
because of the size of available litter boxes the cats sometimes end up 
with some of their pee spattering up along the inside and over the edge of 
the litter box?  (for instance one of my cats  is nearly 20 pounds and not 
fat at all just big, as in long muscular rugged tomcat like build since he 
wasnt fixed till he was two, and no he isn't an expensive breed or hybrid 
my best friend found his mother who was maybe 10 pounds after having her 
kittens  as a pregnant stray) .... i am sure i cant be the only one with 
this issue, but   most litter boxes basically he  ends up peeing  in the 
corners because he really only fits well diagonally  and even then some 
times a bit sprays up over the top edge of the box (its clear he isnt doing 
it on purpose  but it is a problem).  I am guessing there probably are a 
lot of other people who deal with this sort of thing.﻿
comments.author: NocturnalLady1985

comments.text:
I put 10 different boxes but Panda, Kalua, Axl (my cats) still Poo on the 
doning table! Aaaaaaaaaaa 2 boys 1 girl the boy's poo stink!﻿
comments.author: Michelle Tatyana Akila

comments.text: IS the cedar cat litter ok for cats? ﻿
comments.author: kellie lewis

comments.text:
We have two dogs along with our cat and find it so hard to leave cat boxes 
ever where when the dogs will get in to them... what is your suggestion to 
find a compromise? ﻿
comments.author: Heather Vasquez

comments.text:
All this seems highly relative to me, I live in a one bedroom apartment 
with two cats and they do just fine sharing one litter box located in the 
bathroom. This is probably because they're best buds though, if they didn't 
get along then I would definitely consider another litter box﻿
comments.author: MrOnairos

comments.text:
my cat raises his butt as he pees.  he eventually reaches above the top of 
the litter box and ends up peeing on the wall.  I've purchased a plastic 
storage box with the highest sides possible and cut out one side so he can 
go in.  however, he ends up peeing towards where the exit is and I run into 
pee splattered on the floor.  how can I fix this?﻿
comments.author: andree-anne girouard

comments.text:
+ursaucie When I first encountered the problem, that is what I did. I 
bought those storage crates and cut out an opening to one side.  However, 
he still manages to aim towards the opening. It doesn't happen to often 
anymore but still annoying when it does.
comments.author: andree-anne girouard

comments.text:
+andree-anne girouard I have all my litter boxes in plastic storage box. 
They jump in and out and less litter is on the floor. First measure the cat 
box (non-lid one) and then find a storage box it will fit in. Sometimes my 
cat's butt will hang out of the litter box but then the storage box catches 
it. Even our new kitten just jumped in right away.....
comments.author: ursaucie

comments.text: 2 cats: 4-5 toilets﻿
comments.author: Karolina Trgalova

comments.text: How can I stop my cat from spreading litter all over the floor?!﻿
comments.author: RomeroNJ913

comments.text:
I have a cat that is too affectionate, he secrets oils that harm my 
allergies so bad. He is so wonderful but I can not pet him due to 
overstimulation of his oils.. I can't give him away, I tried and had to 
have him back. What so I do to keep the affection lower and play time 
higher?﻿
comments.author: Laura Kivett

comments.text:
if the cat is always getting litter all over the floor is it because the 
box is too small or because it gets caught under her nails? Also, if the 
cat only comes out of the bedroom at night or when no one is home(she's 
a fraidy cat!) will a litter box in the living room help draw her out 
during the day?﻿
comments.author: Rhea Borbotti

comments.text:
I'm noticing that cats seem to be lazy about covering up after they go.  I 
had a female who would poop and then walk away from it...Gross !  It would 
help with odor if they would take a minute to conceal it with their litter. 
 In the past, I witnessed cats spending a lot of time covering.  I suspect 
that their Mom didn't train them correctly.  What's up ?﻿
comments.author: Connie Songbird

comments.text:
:/ My cat does not have a second litter box. Cat only territory is my room 
and the hall, the rest of the house is dog territory. She can hop the gate 
just fine and get on the dog side, but we can't put a litter box on that 
side where she can get to yet the dogs can't.
Also, if cats don't like privacy when doing their business, why did my cat 
decide the best locations were where it never sees the light of day.﻿
comments.author: Keka Winter Star

comments.text:
I love knowing all that!! That helps a whole lot! It makes so much sense 
now and I never knew any of that! My 2 cats share a litterbox just fine now 
and always have and I keep it clean, so since there are no problems, I 
guess I will not add another box.﻿
comments.author: Lizzy Dee

comments.text:
Yes, +Dito Alvarez , I sure do love my kitties!!! I have watched this guy 
for years, but just now finding his youtube channel for some reason.
comments.author: Lizzy Dee

comments.text: u sure love cats don't u liz? I love cats 2!
comments.author: Dito Alvarez

comments.text: Somebody get this man a better mic.﻿
comments.author: Thomas Kirby

comments.text:
After reading many comments , hearing opinions and finally having a cat 
myself (shivering, hungry kitten my brother took from a container bin) it 
seems to me that  there is no universal solution. Ours learned to use the 
litter box on the second day - it is located next to the toilet on the 
first floor. Uses it ever since and  doesn't care much about privacy. She 
likes to wander around on the roof of the house (3rd floor) and I have seen 
her go to the first floor from there, specifically to use the box. She digs 
like crazy though :)﻿
comments.author: timonn

comments.text:
Hi! By having a box per cat and/or keep on cleaning them regularly (if 
people can because people work :D ), isn't it encouraging a wrong behaviour 
for our cats when we're away or not available and that the litter is not as 
clean as usual? They surely will start complaining, and meowing for you to 
come & clean (like we're their maids or something). I got 2 cats and they 
go in the same litter. I had two first but it took some space! I'd like to 
know how you can prevent cats from being spoiled :)﻿
comments.author: Laurie FORTIN FEILER

comments.text:
There are also litter sifters you put under the litter at first (usually 10 
pieces of plastic with holes). Secure it around edges (masking tape on just 
a few points). You just pull up one piece of plastic causing it to sift and 
hold clumps. It worked great until I got the litter robot.

One quick note. If your cat has been using a litter box with  no problems 
and then starts going outside the box and/or leaving it near you it could 
be medical. They are trying to show you they have a problem. ﻿
comments.author: Tara St. Valentine

comments.text:
My cat is kinda weird.  For a while she wasn't going in the box, then she 
started going back into it.  But now her butt isn't all the way in the box 
so she's missing.   She never had these issues when we first got her :/﻿
comments.author: EducatedIdiot97

comments.text: Your advice is really good ﻿
comments.author: Jared Cool guy

comments.text:
I have a Ragdoll. Shes about 6 months old.
Her open litter box it right next to the toilet. I use flushable litter and 
every time i go, i scoop before i flush. Sometimes she will come and pee at 
the same time as me.
I was against cats once. Because of odder.
Turns out its not the cats. Its the owners.
Im in a small apartment and you wouldnt know there was a cat here. Except 
for her toys.﻿
comments.author: TheBaldMan28

comments.text: what is the best place where you can get a cat for free?﻿
comments.author: oksana pavlovska

comments.text: where is the best place where you can get a cat for free?﻿
comments.author: oksana pavlovska

comments.text: Why does my cat scratch the wall outside the litter box after he goes?﻿
comments.author: LeAnne Hooker

comments.text: Can you have too many litter boxes?﻿
comments.author: Brenna Paulie

comments.text:
That's a big "hell no".   Who wants to look at a litter box?  You'll never 
have people over again.  And for those people who say their cat's litter 
box doesn't smell:  yes, it does.  You just can't smell it cause you're 
around it all the time.   When people come into your house, they can smell 
it.﻿
comments.author: missmayflower

comments.text: I  use Everclean unscented, it's the only kind my cat likes.﻿
comments.author: ruthc48

comments.text:
My cat always eats my clothes, my towels , and my stuffed toys.. And then 
he throws them up. What can I do ? ﻿
comments.author: Taiga Aisaka

comments.text: What are your thoughts about the litter maid litter box?﻿
comments.author: valencia carlin

comments.text: Great! Thanks!﻿
comments.author: JediDraper

comments.text:
I have 3 cats and they willing share the littler box no problem. I keep it 
in the bathroom with a hood on it. If I had seen this video before I got my 
rescue cats it sure would deter me from owning a cat and that would mean 3 
more homeless cats out there in a shelter. I think you could be mindful to 
point out using all these extra boxes are for problem cats, not everyday 
cats. ﻿
comments.author: Victoria Reid

comments.text:
Thanks to this video I can now explain to my siblings why Monty doesn't 
like being petted so much. Also I have a small question.

How can you make a three legged cat feel more comfortable around other four 
legged animals? And are there any extra cares I should know for him?

I can tell my cat is jealous of my dog because he can scratch behind both 
ears, while my cat can only scratch behind one.﻿
comments.author: Skull Masher Master Nichimon

comments.text:
hey i have three cats, i didnt know about the mixing up liter boxes till 
today but what if its how your cat goes to the bathroom? im just saying, my 
one cats likes to perch himself on the corner, my other one likes to dig a 
hole then cover it up and their both quite big just thought id ask. love 
your tips and your show! <3 ﻿
comments.author: D'Andra Galaske

comments.text:
What's your opinion on spaying and neutering a cat? And should it or should 
it not happen? ﻿
comments.author: Michelle BunnyRawrzmyCookiez Brett

comments.text:
My house is kind of small so we have the cat litter pan between living room 
and dining room. Seriously, if you just check the cat litter at least twice 
a day, and wash that box at the end of the week for new litter, the box 
isn't going to bother you at all. At least it shouldn't.﻿
comments.author: ooXChrissieXoo

comments.text:
We have a cat that found us. We took her in and she uses a litter box to go 
number one. But when it comes to number 2 the cat goes to the door like a 
dog, and relieves her self in the back yard. If we don't let her outside 
she goes on the floor. Any tips on how to get her to go in the litter box.﻿
comments.author: klsymmy916

comments.text:
I used to have those auto scoop litter boxes and my oldest cat Mylo figured 
out how to unplug it because he clearly hated the sound.  ﻿
comments.author: creations landscape designs / earth friendly landscapes

comments.text:
My cats share one litter box and have never went in the bathroom anywhere 
in the house (except when the one had a UTI). And in fact get very angry if 
I do not clean there litter box. the Siberian cat had issues when he was a 
baby with getting pee stains on his belly fluff so we cleaned his box 
regularly as the vet told us to do. Now if we miss more than 1 day of 
cleaning it he pees on the ramp into the box and screams at me. I also have 
a very large box as they do not like the smaller ones. MY box is in the 
bathroom (not a socially public place) but I made it public by petting them 
and talking sweetly to them when they come in the bathroom and go to the 
bathroom with me and now nearly every time I go to the bathroom the cats 
come with. My cats believe that going to the bathroom is a group event this 
is how I got them to only use there litter box and still have it not such 
an obvious place to all my guests.﻿
comments.author: Lauren Benton

comments.text: my cat has a litter box with an open lid or it has no lid and she fine!﻿
comments.author: AJcupcake lover

comments.text:
Dear Jackson, 
As soon as I have my own apartament, I'd like to adopt a cat. I know, 
easiest way is to go to a pet hospice, but lately I met a cat, which is 
wandering around my block. She's extremly friendly, so I'm concerned about 
her safety, so if noone will adopt her, I'm going to bring her to hospice. 
But what I was going to ask is what can I do for cat to make her removal 
least stressfull? I know, there's no way to avoid putting a cat into a 
transporter and simply move it in another place. But are there any ways to 
make it most easy for an animal? And almost the same thing: when I got the 
apartament, is there any way to make it for cat as friendly ass possible 
before I bring him or her home? I mean, I watched your movies, so I'm aware 
of things like litterboxes, cat trees, cat shelters. Is there something I 
can do before I take a cat from a hospice? I thought of bringing a cat some 
small toys and leaving them in a hospice with the cat for let's say a day. 
And then taking a cat home and spreading toys around the place so cat can 
smell her or his own scent. I'm not sure if I'm thinking right, or maby is 
there any better ways (I bet, there are).
Stay awesome,
Krolewna.
P.s. I'm so sorry if my english is hard to understand, it's not my 
language, but I'm still learning.﻿
comments.author: Królewna Na Ziarnku Fochu

comments.text: Why does my cat like bowties but hates collars﻿
comments.author: Lisa Adams

comments.text:
My cat pees next to the litter box. Not in the litter box... She poos in it 
but she doesn't pee in it. Why??? ﻿
comments.author: Cassie Freitag

comments.text:
Ways to ventilate the litter box...and using large tub to contain messes 
and ease of wood pellets use.﻿
comments.author: Kater Caters to Cats

comments.text:
Hiya, how do I stop my cat from pooing next to the litter box rather in the 
litterbox? He does this every morning, other times he's fine.﻿
comments.author: catfine23

comments.text:
I use one for two cats and clean it about 3 times a week and it works 
perfectly. I wouldn't know where to leave three litterboxes in my house :/ ﻿
comments.author: Odile van der Stap

comments.text:
Jackson how do I keep my cat from leaving litter trails every where he 
goes? He tracks it all over the house.  I have wood floors so maybe that 
makes it worse.﻿
comments.author: SavageXL Bender

comments.text:
I like big 2'x3' concrete mixing pans from HomeDepot. They hold 40+ lbs of 
litter easily. I hope the kitties like them too! But I do need more 
locations, thx.﻿
comments.author: Karl Ruehs

comments.text:
my dog uses the litter box and my cat uses the bathroom outside.....weird 
huh?﻿
comments.author: ilovesnowball33

comments.text:
I've always had 1 litterbox for my 2 cats. I did this before actually know 
that I would need 3 for my 2. I have never had a problem with this so I 
didn't change anything. It seems that if I change what the cats are 
comfortable with, then I have an issue.﻿
comments.author: Trina Bolton

comments.text:
I have two cats and two litter boxes and they are both in the bathroom. 
They have always been in the bathroom and I have never had a problem with 
it.
But putting litter boxes behind washing machines and in the garage is just 
weird... Would you wanna go pooping behind machines or in the garage? 
Probably not!

Me and my cats use the bathroom at the same time, haha. We're all doing our 
thing.﻿
comments.author: SlaytheAngels

comments.text:
+SlaytheAngels that is so funny! My first cat and I would use the AM 
bathroom together yawning together! LOL
comments.author: Lizzy Dee

comments.text:
+SlaytheAngels 
Lol same here. For my cats, the bathroom is like a social place, for some 
reason they love to come in to get petted. 
Also I'm with you with the litter box in a garage or behind a washing 
machine. Who wants to go through the pain of cleaning a litter box in such 
placea? Garages are for the most part messy places and laundry rooms are 
kind of small.
comments.author: Lillykins

comments.text:
I have a whole room for my cat and my cat can run in because the door way 
is blocked with a gate and it has a gap so my cat can run in , with her cat 
litter in there and it's a box one with a lid the reason my has a room is 
to escape my dog. Because my dog get crazy when play with my cat. 
﻿
comments.author: Sky .Hawk

comments.text: So Gotta Have 7 Litter Boxes ? 0_o﻿
comments.author: Patricia Nessa

comments.text:
So right!!  I am a breeder - over 40 years standing! and after one year, I 
never used a hooded box.  My cats hated it. All my litter boxes are, four 
sided, open. Deoderizers - your point is exactly right:  keep your boxes 
clean:  no smell.  Ta Dah!  or is that just DUH?  If Yiu feel you must, 
sprinkle the fresh litter with baking soda.  But empty empty empty.  is the 
key.﻿
comments.author: Jeanne Culbert

comments.text:
To late I guess. But how do you inspire a free-ranging cat with cat-flap to 
do it's ting outside at least when it's out and about. -Instead of going 
back in to use the litter before heading out again?﻿
comments.author: MalawisLilleKanal

comments.text:
~Why are ceiling fans scary to cats?
~Is catnip harmful or addictive to cats?
~Is peeing next to the kitty litter box a sign that the kitty litter isn't 
changed enough?﻿
comments.author: Jessica Davison

comments.text:
I put the litter box in the bathroom where it is the right place to go. I 
am not living in a cat's world. The Cat is living in my world. The cat 
adjusts just fine. I am potty training the cat and she is adjusting fine. I 
will also put a halter on her and train her to be on a leash. It will be 
training using only love, not punishment A frisky cat is a happy cat. My 
cat is always frisky and playful. ﻿
comments.author: Brian Scott Miller (BS, BM, Scott.)

comments.text:
Hi Jackson, First thing first, I really like your show. It is nice to see 
someone who truthfully respect cats and understands them.
Our household is made of 2 dogs (a shiba and a japanese akita) and 2 ladies 
maine coon cats...
Right now, there are two litterboxes, the ladies cats have their privacy 
where they are not disturbed by the dogs, if unsupervized, at the first 
floor [and we use a baby fence so the cats may go down whenever they like, 
but the shiba cannot pass through it, if we are not there]... note : they 
did prefer to have the current litterboxes side by side after proposing 
different spots to them though :) "Belle de Jour", soon 9 years old, really 
dislikes whenever I disturb her routine... (she is a diva with sweet 
temperament, and a dweller type of cat) and Juvamine is the climber type, 
and a real energetic and lively young lady... This summer, Juvamine may 
have babies.
I was thinking of adding 1 or 2 other litterboxes in the house, as I intend 
to keep 1 kitten and so there will be 3 cats in the house.
Do you know of good litterboxes, a bit more design or original that would 
suit the tall size of a maine coon cat ? (possibly some models I can 
purchase in europe without too much hassle or that could be shipped to 
europe. I live in France)﻿
comments.author: Pecky ShiFrit

comments.text:
I have a blind cat; she wasn't born that way, her head got slammed in the 
door when she was a few weeks old. I'm having a problem with the litter 
box. She would always go to the bathroom to do her business so I put her 
box in there. she still uses the floor,so I get her up early every morning 
and feed her carry her to her box she uses it. I do the same when I go home 
for lunch she uses it and after work I watch her. Now she's in heat she 
don't want to use it. I put her in she jumps out after 3 or 4 times I give 
up, but if I shut her up in the bathroom she gets in it by herself but only 
when I shut her up. I don't like doing that. I don't know what to do. She's 
not like any cat I have ever had. When I call her she comes running to me 
she walks around and around the coffee table or the ottoman all the time. 
She's nearly a year old now. I hope you can help me﻿

Get her spayed & while you're getting that done ask your vet for help with 
the habitual inappropriate elimination she has developed because you waited 
so long to get her fixed.
comments.author: Henrika16

comments.text:
Just adopted a 11 month old cat he is the sweetest cat we need to get him 
neutered. I heard I should put newspaper in the liter box a few days after 
he gets fixed?? Also he has friendly bit us during play is this ok??﻿
comments.author: bree doxey

comments.text:
I am just wondering why a lot of cat owners seem to have litter boxes that 
are covered. My cats are large so they don't fit in a regular box. When I 
tried many years ago, it was an epic fail on my part.

I went to the local hardware store and bought a couple of 60 liter rubber 
pails/water troughs (they come in different sizes and colours).

OK, they are not pretty, but they are large and deep enough for my cats to 
dig as much as they like without the litter covering the floor afterwards.﻿
comments.author: Janie Doe

comments.text:
One of my cats will ONLY poop in a covered box.... she will pee in either 
covered or uncovered though. I also use rubbermaid bins with holes in the 
side for my other boxes. One of my cats sprays so high that they are the 
only thing that can contain her pee INSIDE the box and not 5feet across the 
floor. (We had the far more aesthetically pleasing NVR-Miss for awhile, but 
even that wasn't high-sided enough.) So, yeah it really just depends on the 
cat. Oh I should add the sprayer is tiny at 6pounds, so its not like she 
needs the space because of size, she's just insecure about litter boxes and 
needs to be able to move around and spray to her hearts content.
comments.author: Henrika16

comments.author: beargirl fog

comments.text: Can I put my cat's litter box outside or teach her to go outside? ﻿
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:
+Keightley P I live away from the city on a road that is not very busy. I 
believe she is safe outside, so she is an indoor/outdoor cat. I have 
trained her to go outside. It is really nice not having that smell in your 
house, however I am still cleaning a litter box. I started by moving her 
litterbox near the back door, and left it their for a few weeks. I then 
moved it to the back porch. She usually will now go outside where ever she 
wants, but will still go in the box when it's rainy or cold.
comments.author: Emma Claridge

comments.text:
+John Dalton My cat was a feral kitten when we got her. She had just been 
weaned and I think she had lived her entire life outdoors.
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:
+John Dalton Thank you for your advice. My cat is limited to a fenced in 
backyard and she is only out there when we are home. She has all of her 
vaccines up to date and we treat her for fleas and ticks. All of the plants 
out there are pet safe and we even grow some catnip. She is spayed and my 
dog always goes out there with her. I normally am pretty comfortable with 
her in the backyard, and she has been much happier since we decided to let 
her go outside as she wished.
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:

make it befor Meal (3 Meals a Day). What i'm trying to say. The Hallway is 
the most Area in that we are. If we have to go in the Kitchen or the Toilet 
or somewhere else. We have to get trough that Hallway :D﻿

comments.text:
Hi From Danmark thanks for some fine shows  they are very good I like them 
,can you help me ,I have a problem  ? I got seven cats , and they all can 
go outside they can take a long walk if they want to, and the Sea is not 
far either I live in a 5 rooms apartment also where other people live 
upstairs I live on the floor , I  take the cats poop up outside if I see it 
in  the garden or other places near the house  ,but suddenly my 13-14  year 
old mama cat Dayzi ,she is peeing where I go in and out of the door , the 
front door I now have to use clorin ,so people don't  begin to ask about 
the smell  because her idea is to go on every day ones a day to pee there, 
while I am a sleep mostly , now I am putting news paper there  I have to go 
out of that door front door, there is 4 doors in that space so it actually 
dont matter  I have to walk in and out  of them all and in that place there 
is no room for anything the doors  they are  next to eachother in a sqare 
 ??? ,ones I thought she finely stoped , but no ,after I got home , I 
looked away to do other stuff she peed there  again sometimes it's a lake

is her  ,I now have desided to put newspaper there, I am very sad because I 
dont know why she is doing it,  I still have to go in and out of that door 
and she can go out if she want to  of their own door she is in charge, the 
children respect her too, I can't afford so many things because I am  alone 
 at the moment   ,and It is the wintertime  it seems like she is bored or 
something  she is lieing on the  dinner table and sleeping  and have a good 
time with that,  they all like me I thought and also they  can't have 
babies  4 boys 3 girls ,  I always try to understand their needs ,I have 
one litterbox downstairs  ,but still , they can go out to where ever  and 
have always done so , if hey want and that have worked fine always  ,but 
she want to pee in front of the door where I walk in and out..That make me 
 so very sad. What can it be ??? ﻿

comments.author: Jack Hume

comments.text:
My tenant, who lives in my upstairs loft, has a box she rarely changes and 
the odor is horrific.Her cats hate it, and poop and pee on my carpeting, on 
her bed - unfortunately, I desperately need her rent income and she's very 
touchy. She has some personality issues and it's hard to get her to admit 
she ever does anything wrong. She gets mad if I clean the box when she's 
gone. What the hell can I do? I'm tired of scrubbing it off the carpet, 
wiping it up from the hard floor, washing it out of throw pillows - I 
believe she no longer smells it. She seems oblivious.﻿
comments.author: Ocmeditor Editor

comments.text: +Ocmeditor Editor She might also have a mental illness
comments.author: 923rememberme

comments.text:
Unfortunately there's a strong chance that the cat has an untreated UTI or 
similar which is going untreated. You can always try hiding a secret litter 
box you maintain like the other poster said, or "gift" her an extra litter 
box that "just happened to come your way" to spread out the options in 
between cleaning. Placement matters too, which you don't really have much 
control of, such as avoiding laundry machines - one of our older cats used 
to pee on the couch and it drove us crazy until we realized she only did it 
when she needed to pee and someone was running the laundry and it scared 
her. Recently she started peeing all over again, and she went to the vet 
and turns out she has asthma and every time she tried to use her (very 
dusty) litter she'd get an asthma attack. Changed the litter to a non-dusty 
brand and problem solved.
comments.author: Henrika16

comments.text:
+Ocmeditor Editor Dependig on how free the cat is to move about, The easy 
route might be to have your own "secret litterbox" that you maintain. The 
cat will probably choose it over the alternatives, and you get some sort of 
half-baked solution.
comments.author: MalawisLilleKanal

comments.text:
I did. Nothing's changed. I'd rather skip the formalities and just shoot 
her.
comments.author: Ocmeditor Editor
